tensorgraph.layers.conv module¶

class tensorgraph.layers.conv.Atrous_Conv2D(num_filters=None, rate=1, kernel_size=(3, 3), filter=None, b=None, padding='VALID', stddev=0.1)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Parameters:
  • filter (tensorflow.Variable) – 4D Variable of shape [kernel_size[0], kernel_size[1], input_channels, num_filters]
  • b (tensorflow.Variable) – 1D Variable of shape [num_filters]
  • stddev (float) – standard deviation for initializing the filter
  • padding –

    SAME: same as input shape

    VALID: 0 padding, output shape = h - 2((k+(k-1)(r-1))/2)
    where k: kernel_size, r: rate and effective filter size is k+(k-1)(r-1) with (r-1) zeros inserted between every horizontal and vertical neighbouring filter values.
class tensorgraph.layers.conv.AvgPooling(poolsize=(2, 2), stride=(1, 1), padding='VALID')[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Average pooling layer

Parameters:
  • stride – two-dimensional tuple (a, b), the separation horizontally a or vertically b between two pools
  • padding –

    SAME:

    >>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[0] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[1] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0

    >>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[0] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[1] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0

class tensorgraph.layers.conv.Conv3D(num_filters=None, kernel_size=(3, 3, 3), stride=(1, 1, 1), filter=None, b=None, padding='VALID', stddev=0.1)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

3d convolution

Parameters:
  • kernel_size – [filter_depth, filter_height, filter_width]
  • stride – [stride_depth, stride_height, stride_width]
  • filter (tensorflow.Variable) – 5D Variable of shape [filter_depth, filter_height, filter_width, input_channels, num_filters]
  • b (tensorflow.Variable) – 1D Variable of shape [num_filters]
  • stddev (float) – standard deviation for initializing the filter
  • padding –

    SAME:

    >>> pad_along_depth = ((out_depth - 1) * stride[0] + filter_depth - in_depth)
>>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[1] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[2] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0
class tensorgraph.layers.conv.Conv3D_Transpose(num_filters=None, kernel_size=(3, 3, 3), stride=(1, 1, 1), filter=None, b=None, padding='VALID', stddev=0.1)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

  • b (tensorflow.Variable) – 1D Variable of shape [num_filters]
  • stddev (float) – standard deviation for initializing the filter
  • padding –

    >>> pad_along_depth = ((out_depth - 1) * stride[0] + filter_depth - in_depth)
>>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[1] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[2] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0
class tensorgraph.layers.conv.Depthwise_Conv2D(num_filters=None, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), filter=None, b=None, padding='VALID', stddev=0.1)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Descriptions:
Depthwise 2-D convolution. Given an input tensor of shape [batch, in_height, in_width, in_channels] and a filter tensor of shape [filter_height, filter_width, in_channels, channel_multiplier] containing in_channels convolutional filters of depth 1, depthwise_conv2d applies a different filter to each input channel (expanding from 1 channel to channel_multiplier channels for each), then concatenates the results together. The output has in_channels * channel_multiplier channels.
Parameters:
  • filter (tensorflow.Variable) – 4D Variable of shape [kernel_size[0], kernel_size[1], input_channels, num_filters]
  • b (tensorflow.Variable) – 1D Variable of shape [num_filters]
  • stddev (float) – standard deviation for initializing the filter
  • padding –

    SAME:

    >>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[0] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[1] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0
class tensorgraph.layers.conv.MaxPooling(poolsize=(2, 2), stride=(1, 1), padding='VALID')[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Pooling layer

Parameters:
  • stride – two-dimensional tuple (a, b), the separation horizontally a or vertically b between two pools
  • padding –

    SAME``:

    >>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[0] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[1] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0
class tensorgraph.layers.conv.MaxPooling3D(poolsize=(2, 2, 2), stride=(1, 1, 1), padding='VALID')[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

3D pooling layer

Parameters:
  • input – A Tensor. Must be one of the following types: float32. Shape [batch, depth, rows, cols, channels] tensor to pool over.
  • and stride (poolsize) – three-dimensional tuple (d, h, w)
  • padding –

    SAME:

    >>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[0] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[1] + filter_width - in_width)

    VALID: padding is always 0
class tensorgraph.layers.conv.ZeroPad(pad_along_height=[0, 0], pad_along_width=[0, 0])[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Parameters:pad (tuple) – pad_along_height = (h_top, h_bottom) pad_along_width = (w_left, w_right)

Example

>>> image = (a, b, c, d) and pad_along_height = (h_top, h_bottom) and
>>> pad_along_width = (w_left, w_right)
>>> padded_mage = (a, b+h_top+h_bottom, c+w_left+w_right, d)

class tensorgraph.layers.linear.LinearMasked(this_dim=None, W=None, b=None, mask=None, stddev=0.1)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Description:
This is a fully connected layer with an applied mask for partial connections
Parameters:
  • this_dim (int) – dimension of this layer
  • name (string) – name of the layer
  • W (tensor variable) – Weight of 2D tensor matrix
  • b (tensor variable) – bias of 2D tensor matrix
  • mask (numpy.ndarray or tensorflow placeholder) – mask for partial connection
  • params (list) – a list of params in layer that can be updated
class tensorgraph.layers.linear.SparseLinear(prev_dim=None, this_dim=None, W=None, b=None, batchsize=None, stddev=0.1)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Description:
This is a fully connected layer with sparse inputs are two tensors one is index tensor of dimension [N, prev_dim] and another one is value tensor of [N]
Parameters:
  • prev_dim (int) – dimension of previous layer
  • this_dim (int) – dimension of this layer
  • name (string) – name of the layer
  • W (tensor variable) – Weight of 2D tensor matrix
  • b (tensor variable) – bias of 2D tensor matrix
  • params (list) – a list of params in layer that can be updated

class tensorgraph.layers.merge.SequenceMask(maxlen)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.merge.Merge

Description:
Mask the sequence of shape [batchsize, max_seq_len, :, ..] at the second dimension by using a mask tensor representing the first N positions of each row.

Example

>>> mask = tf.sequence_mask(lengths=[1, 3, 2], maxlen=5) =
>>>       [[True, False, False, False, False],
>>>       [True, True, True, False, False],
>>>       [True, True, False, False, False]]
>>> y = X * mask

class tensorgraph.layers.misc.Slim(start, layers, merge=<tensorgraph.layers.merge.Sum object>)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseModel

Slim converts Tensorgraph Sequential Mode into Functional Mode. Similar to Keras Sequential and Functional.

Example how to use Slim class SampleModel(BaseModel):

@BaseModel.init_name_scope def __init__(self):

self.startnode = StartNode([None]) conv1 = Slim([self.startnode], [Conv2D(num_filters=16, kernel_size=(3,3), stride=(1,1), padding=’SAME’)]) flat = Slim([conv1.endnode], [Flatten()]) batch = Slim([flat.endnode], [BatchNormalization()]) l1 = Slim([batch.endnode], [Linear(this_dim=30) ]) l2 = Slim([l1.endnode], [Linear(this_dim=10) ]) l3 = Slim([l2.endnode], [Linear(this_dim=5) ]) self.endnode = EndNode(prev=[l3.endnode])
class tensorgraph.layers.misc.Squeeze(squeeze_dims=None)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Parameters:
  • squeeze_dims – An optional list of ints. Defaults to []. If specified,
  • squeezes the dimensions listed. The dimension index starts at 0. (only) –
  • is an error to squeeze a dimension that is not 1. Refer to tensorflow (It) –
  • details. (for) –
class tensorgraph.layers.misc.Transpose(perm)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Example

>>> X = [3, 5, 9], Y = tf.transpose(X, perm=[0,2,1]) gives
>>> Y = [3, 9, 5]

tensorgraph.layers.normalization module¶

class tensorgraph.layers.normalization.BatchNormalization(axis=-1, momentum=0.99, epsilon=0.001, center=True, scale=True, beta_initializer=<tensorflow.python.ops.init_ops.Zeros object>, gamma_initializer=<tensorflow.python.ops.init_ops.Ones object>, moving_mean_initializer=<tensorflow.python.ops.init_ops.Zeros object>, moving_variance_initializer=<tensorflow.python.ops.init_ops.Ones object>, beta_regularizer=None, gamma_regularizer=None, beta_constraint=None, gamma_constraint=None, renorm=False, renorm_clipping=None, renorm_momentum=0.99, fused=None)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Reference:
Batch Normalization: Accelerating Deep Network Training by Reducing Internal Covariate Shift http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03167
Parameters:
  • axis – Integer, the axis that should be normalized (typically the features axis). For instance, after a Conv2D layer with data_format=”channels_first”, set axis=1 in BatchNormalization.
  • momentum – Momentum for the moving average.
  • epsilon – Small float added to variance to avoid dividing by zero.
  • center – If True, add offset of beta to normalized tensor. If False, beta is ignored.
  • scale – If True, multiply by gamma. If False, gamma is not used. When the next layer is linear (also e.g. nn.relu), this can be disabled since the scaling can be done by the next layer.
  • beta_initializer – Initializer for the beta weight.
  • gamma_initializer – Initializer for the gamma weight.
  • moving_mean_initializer – Initializer for the moving mean.
  • moving_variance_initializer – Initializer for the moving variance.
  • beta_regularizer – Optional regularizer for the beta weight.
  • gamma_regularizer – Optional regularizer for the gamma weight.
  • beta_constraint – An optional projection function to be applied to the beta weight after being updated by an Optimizer (e.g. used to implement norm constraints or value constraints for layer weights). The function must take as input the unprojected variable and must return the projected variable (which must have the same shape). Constraints are not safe to use when doing asynchronous distributed training.
  • gamma_constraint – An optional projection function to be applied to the gamma weight after being updated by an Optimizer.
  • renorm – Whether to use Batch Renormalization (https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.03275). This adds extra variables during training. The inference is the same for either value of this parameter.
  • renorm_clipping – A dictionary that may map keys ‘rmax’, ‘rmin’, ‘dmax’ to scalar Tensors used to clip the renorm correction. The correction (r, d) is used as corrected_value = normalized_value * r + d, with r clipped to [rmin, rmax], and d to [-dmax, dmax]. Missing rmax, rmin, dmax are set to inf, 0, inf, respectively.
  • renorm_momentum – Momentum used to update the moving means and standard deviations with renorm. Unlike momentum, this affects training and should be neither too small (which would add noise) nor too large (which would give stale estimates). Note that momentum is still applied to get the means and variances for inference.
  • fused – if True, use a faster, fused implementation if possible. If None, use the system recommended implementation.

Note

>>> # To use this normalization, apply update ops below to update the mean and variance
>>> from tensorflow.python.framework import ops
>>> optimizer = tf.train.AdamOptimizer(learning_rate)
>>> update_ops = ops.get_collection(ops.GraphKeys.UPDATE_OPS)
>>> with ops.control_dependencies(update_ops):
>>>     train_op = optimizer.minimize(train_cost_sb)
class tensorgraph.layers.normalization.L2_Normalize(dim)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

dim (int or list of ints): dimension to normalize

class tensorgraph.layers.normalization.LRN(depth_radius=None, bias=None, alpha=None, beta=None)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Description:

Local Response Normalization. The 4-D input tensor is treated as a 3-D array of 1-D vectors (along the last dimension), and each vector is normalized independently. Within a given vector, each component is divided by the weighted, squared sum of inputs within depth_radius. In detail,

>>> sqr_sum[a, b, c, d] =   sum(input[a, b, c, d - depth_radius : d + depth_radius + 1] ** 2)
>>> output = input / (bias + alpha * sqr_sum) ** beta
Parameters:
  • depth_radius (optional int) – defaults to 5. 0-D. Half-width of the 1-D normalization window.
  • bias (optional float) – Defaults to 1. An offset (usually positive to avoid dividing by 0).
  • alpha (optional float) – Defaults to 1. A scale factor, usually positive.
  • beta (optional float) – Defaults to 0.5. An exponent.

class tensorgraph.layers.recurrent.DynamicBiLSTM(fw_num_units, bw_num_units, const_seq_len=False, state_is_tuple=True, scope=None)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Description:
BiDynamicLSTM is for sequences with dynamic length.
Parameters:
  • scope (str) – scope for the cells. For RNN with the same scope name, the rnn cell will be reused.
  • const_seq_len (bool) – if true, will use a constant sequence length equal to the max_time. state_below will just be singular input instead of tuple.
class tensorgraph.layers.recurrent.DynamicLSTM(num_units, const_seq_len=False, state_is_tuple=True, scope=None)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Description:
DynamicLSTM is for sequences with dynamic length.
Parameters:
  • scope (str) – scope for the cells. For RNN with the same scope name, the rnn cell will be reused.
  • const_seq_len (bool) – if true, will use a constant sequence length equal to the max_time. state_below will just be singular input instead of tuple.
class tensorgraph.layers.recurrent.LSTM(num_units, return_idx=[0, 1, 2], initial_state=None, state_is_tuple=True, scope=None)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.layers.template.BaseLayer

Description:
LSTM is for sequences with fixed length.
Parameters:
  • scope (str) – scope for the cells. For RNN with the same scope name, the rnn cell will be reused.
  • initial_state – An initial state for the RNN. If cell.state_size is an integer, this must be a Tensor of appropriate type and shape [batch_size, cell.state_size]. If cell.state_size is a tuple, this should be a tuple of tensors having shapes [batch_size, s] for s in cell.state_size.
  • return_idx (list) – list of index from the rnn outputs to return from [outputs, context, last_hid], indexes has to fall into [0, 1, 2]

Seq2Seq model

static check_y()[source]¶

Check if the output list contains one element or a list, if contains only one element, return the element, if contains more than one element, returns the entire list.
